document.masterDocTitle: The Luciolinae of S. E. Asia and the Australopacific region: a revisionary checklist (Coleoptera: Lampyridae) including description of three new genera and 13 new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Luciolinae of S. E. Asia and the Australopacific region: a revisionary checklist (Coleoptera: Lampyridae) including description of three new genera and 13 new species

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 175−179. Asymmetricata ovalis female (Chiang Mai QSBG). 175 abdominal segments 7, 8, ventral; 176, 178, 179 reproductive system: 176 entire system SDG to right of picture, ovipositor to left; 177 female genitalia styli to foot of page 178 ventral outline of median oviduct plate with valvifers of ovipositor to right; 179 left lateral with median oviduct plate from side and ovipositor at bottom left.. Scale lines are 1 mm.

Diagnosis . Most similar in dorsal colouration to
As. circumdata
, distinguished by the bipartite LO in V7. The Goa specimens have 2 dark median pronotal spots and are tentatively included here. Rat District specimens have elytra pale brown with basal section darker brown and resemble
As. humeralis
comb. nov.
Female macropterous; abdomen coloured as for female
As. circumdata
; V8 posterior margin widely emarginated with posterolateral corners narrowly angulate; median oviduct plate elongate, longer than wide with anterior margin rounded and lateral ‘arms’ subtriangular in outline, being longer than high ( Figs 175−179 ).

Remarks.
Luciola aemula Olivier 1891
was based on a female taken in Myanmar (as ‘ Burma Monts Carin’). Specimens of
As. ovalis
were also taken at this site and the synonymy is based on the similarity of colour patterns and overlapping localities.

Adults of
Asymmetricata ovalis
are not as widely distributed as
As. circumdata
and in Thailand were found in natural habitats and only recorded from seven locations which are widely distributed throughout the Northern region. The elevation range of habitats are about
200 m .
to above 1,200 m . A few adult males were collected during rainy season between May and early July (Nak-eiam 2015).
